problems.title: Draw a Square
problems.statementHtml:
The pink soldiers have given you 44 distinct points on the plane. The 44 points' coordinates are (−l,0)(−l,0), (r,0)(r,0), (0,−d)(0,−d), (0,u)(0,u) correspondingly, where ll, rr, dd, uu are positive integers.

Please determine if it is possible to draw a square∗∗ with the given points as its vertices.

∗∗A square is defined as a polygon consisting of 44 vertices, of which all sides have equal length and all inner angles are equal. No two edges of the polygon may intersect each other.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains four integers ll, rr, dd, uu (1≤l,r,d,u≤101≤l,r,d,u≤10).
problems.outputSpecHtml:
For each test case, if you can draw a square using the four points, output "Yes". Otherwise, output "No".

You can output the answer in any case. For example, the strings "yEs", "yes", and "YES" will also be recognized as positive responses.
problems.noteHtml:
On the first test case, the four given points form a square, so the answer is "Yes".

On the second test case, the four given points do not form a square, so the answer is "No".

problems.title: The Third Side
problems.statementHtml:
The pink soldiers have given you a sequence a consisting of n positive integers.

You must repeatedly perform the following operation until there is only 1 element left.

Please find the maximum possible value of the only last element in the sequence a.

∗A triangle with side lengths a, b, c is non-degenerate when a+b>c, a+c>b, b+c>a.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases t (1≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains a single integer n (1≤n≤2⋅105).

The second line of each test case contains n integers a1,a2,…,an (1≤ai≤1000) — the elements of the sequence a.

It is guaranteed that the sum of n over all test cases does not exceed 2⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output the maximum possible value of the only last element on a separate line.
problems.noteHtml:
On the first test case, there is already only one element. The value of the only last element is 10.

On the second test case, a is initially [998,244,353]. The following series of operations is valid:

  1. Erase a2=244 and a3=353, and append 596 to the end of a. a is now [998,596].
  2. Erase a1=998 and a2=596, and append 1593 to the end of a. a is now [1593].

It can be shown that the only last element cannot be greater than 1593. Therefore, the answer is 1593.

problems.title: XOR and Triangle
problems.statementHtml:
This time, the pink soldiers have given you an integer xx (x≥2x≥2).

Please determine if there exists a positive integer yy that satisfies the following conditions.

Additionally, if there exists such an integer yy, output any.

∗∗A triangle with side lengths aa, bb, cc is non-degenerate when a+b>ca+b>c, a+c>ba+c>b, b+c>ab+c>a.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤20001≤t≤2000). The description of the test cases follows.

The only line of each test case contains a single integer xx (2≤x≤1092≤x≤109).
problems.outputSpecHtml:
For each test case, print one integer on a separate line. The integer you must output is as follows:

  • If there exists an integer yy satisfying the conditions, output the value of yy (1≤y<x1≤y<x);
  • Otherwise, output −1−1.

If there exist multiple integers that satisfy the conditions, you may output any.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first test case, there exists a non-degenerate triangle with side lengths 33, 55, and 3⊕5=63⊕5=6. Therefore, y=3y=3 is a valid answer.

In the second test case, 11 is the only possible candidate for yy, but it cannot make a non-degenerate triangle. Therefore, the answer is −1−1.

problems.title: Counting Points
problems.statementHtml:
The pink soldiers drew n circles with their center on the x-axis of the plane. Also, they have told that the sum of radii is exactly m∗.

Please find the number of integer points inside or on the border of at least one circle. Formally, the problem is defined as follows.

You are given an integer sequence x1,x2,…,xn and a positive integer sequence r1,r2,…,rn, where it is known that ∑ni=1ri=m.

You must count the number of integer pairs (x,y) that satisfy the following condition.

∗Is this information really useful? Don't ask me; I don't really know.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases t (1≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains two integers n and m (1≤n≤m≤2⋅105).

The second line of each test case contains x1,x2,…,xn — the centers of the circles (−109≤xi≤109).

The third line of each test case contains r1,r2,…,rn — the radii of the circles (1≤ri, ∑ni=1ri=m).

It is guaranteed that the sum of m over all test cases does not exceed 2⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output the number of integer points satisfying the condition on a separate line.
problems.noteHtml:
On the first test case, the circle with r1=1 is completely inside the circle with r2=2. Therefore, you only have to count the number of integer points inside the latter. There are 13 integer points such that x2+y2≤22, so the answer is 13.

On the second test case, the circle with r1=1 is not completely inside the circle with r2=2. There are 3 additional points that are inside the first circle but not inside the second circle, so the answer is 3+13=16.

problems.title: Counting Necessary Nodes
problems.statementHtml:
A quadtree is a tree data structure in which each node has at most four children and accounts for a square-shaped region.

Formally, for all tuples of nonnegative integers k,a,b≥0k,a,b≥0, there exists exactly one node accounting for the following region∗∗.

[a⋅2k,(a+1)⋅2k]×[b⋅2k,(b+1)⋅2k][a⋅2k,(a+1)⋅2k]×[b⋅2k,(b+1)⋅2k]

All nodes whose region is larger than 1×11×1 contain four children corresponding to the regions divided equally into four, and the nodes whose region is 1×11×1 correspond to the leaf nodes of the tree.

The Frontman hates the widespread misconception, such that the quadtree can perform range queries in O(logn)O(log⁡n) time when there are nn leaf nodes inside the region. In fact, sometimes it is necessary to query much more than O(logn)O(log⁡n) regions for this, and the time complexity is O(n)O(n) in some extreme cases. Thus, the Frontman came up with this task to educate you about this worst case of the data structure.

The pink soldiers have given you a finite region [l1,r1]×[l2,r2][l1,r1]×[l2,r2], where lili and riri (li<rili<ri) are nonnegative integers. Please find the minimum number of nodes that you must choose in order to make the union of regions accounted for by the chosen nodes exactly the same as the given region. Here, two sets of points are considered different if there exists a point included in one but not in the other.

∗∗Regions are sets of points with real coordinates, where the point (x,y)(x,y) is included in the region [p,q]×[r,s][p,q]×[r,s] if and only if p≤x≤qp≤x≤q and r≤y≤sr≤y≤s. Here, ×× formally refers to Cartesian product of sets.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The only line of each test case contains four integers l1l1, r1r1, l2l2, r2r2 — the boundaries of the region in each axis (0≤li<ri≤1060≤li<ri≤106).
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output the minimum number of nodes necessary to satisfy the condition on a separate line.
problems.noteHtml:
On the first test case, the given region is [0,1]×[1,2][0,1]×[1,2]. There is one node accounting for [0,1]×[1,2][0,1]×[1,2]. Choosing this node, the answer is 11.

On the second test case, the given region is [0,2]×[0,2][0,2]×[0,2]. There is one node accounting for [0,2]×[0,2][0,2]×[0,2]. Choosing this node, the answer is 11.

On the third test case, the given region is [1,3]×[1,3][1,3]×[1,3]. There is no node that accounts for [1,3]×[1,3][1,3]×[1,3]. Instead, you can make the union of regions exactly the same as [1,3]×[1,3][1,3]×[1,3] by choosing the following 44 nodes:

  • A leaf node accounting for [1,2]×[1,2][1,2]×[1,2];
  • A leaf node accounting for [1,2]×[2,3][1,2]×[2,3];
  • A leaf node accounting for [2,3]×[1,2][2,3]×[1,2];
  • A leaf node accounting for [2,3]×[2,3][2,3]×[2,3].

It can be shown that it is impossible to make the union of regions exactly the same as [1,3]×[1,3][1,3]×[1,3] with less than 44 nodes. Therefore, the answer is 44.

On the fourth test case, the given region is [0,2]×[1,5][0,2]×[1,5]. You can make the union of regions exactly the same as [0,2]×[1,5][0,2]×[1,5] by choosing the following 55 nodes:

  • A leaf node accounting for [0,1]×[1,2][0,1]×[1,2];
  • A leaf node accounting for [1,2]×[1,2][1,2]×[1,2];
  • A non-leaf node accounting for [0,2]×[2,4][0,2]×[2,4];
  • A leaf node accounting for [0,1]×[4,5][0,1]×[4,5];
  • A leaf node accounting for [1,2]×[4,5][1,2]×[4,5].

It can be shown that it is impossible to make the union of regions exactly the same as [0,2]×[1,5][0,2]×[1,5] with less than 55 nodes. Therefore, the answer is 55.

problems.title: Game With Triangles: Season 2
problems.statementHtml:
There is a regular polygon with nn sides (n≥3n≥3). The vertices are indexed as 1,2,…,n1,2,…,n in clockwise order. On each vertex ii, the pink soldiers have written a positive integer aiai. With this regular polygon, you will play a game defined as follows.

Initially, your score is 00. Then, you perform the following operation any number of times to increase your score.

Your objective is to maximize the score. Please find the maximum score you can get from this game.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains a single integer nn — the number of vertices (3≤n≤4003≤n≤400).

The second line of each test case contains a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an — the integers written on vertices (1≤ai≤10001≤ai≤1000).

It is guaranteed that the sum of n3n3 over all test cases does not exceed 40034003.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output the maximum score you can get on a separate line.
problems.noteHtml:
On the first test case, you can draw only one triangle. The maximum score 66 is found by drawing the triangle with i=1i=1, j=2j=2, k=3k=3.

On the second test case, you can draw only one triangle. The maximum score 2424 is found by drawing the triangle with i=1i=1, j=3j=3, k=4k=4.

On the third test case, you can draw two triangles. There is a series of two operations that leads to the score 55, which is the maximum.

On the fourth test case, you can draw two triangles. However, drawing two triangles leads to a score of either 6+5=116+5=11, 15+2=1715+2=17, or 10+3=1310+3=13. The maximum score 3030 is found by drawing only one triangle with i=2i=2, j=4j=4, k=6k=6.

On the fifth test case, you can draw three triangles. The maximum score 732732 is found by drawing three triangles as follows.

tutorial.contentHtml:
Well, that was a blast, certainly. I hope that you... learned a lot from the contest. I wouldn't say "enjoy the contest", I know most of you hate geometry, I get you. But please do remember that, at least I did try my best to make every problem as high quality as possible. Like, if you don't get familiar with thinking about geometry now, you might never get familiar with it in the future. Though I apologize that E was quite hard, I suggest you to upsolve or read the editorials of the tasks you could not solve. I am telling you, it will be an experience that will make you improve much more from now.

Solution codes will be posted after the open hack phase. They are now added.

Spoiler

2074A - Draw a Square

Editorial

2074A - Draw a Square

For the given four points to make a square, we can see that the following must hold:

  • l, r, d, u must all be equal.

The proof is left as a practice for the reader, but generally, it can be proved easily by seeing that the square is both a rhombus and a rectangle.

The problem is solved in O(1) per test case.
